events.title: Start of the Cuban Revolution
events.description: Fidel Castro, along with his revolutionaries, attacked the Moncada Barracks in Santiago de Cuba, marking the beginning of the Cuban Revolution against the Batista regime.
events.significance: This event is considered the start of the Cuban Revolution, which eventually led to the overthrow of Fulgencio Batista and the establishment of a socialist government in Cuba under Castro.

events.title: Creation of the United Nations Charter
events.description: The United Nations Charter was signed by 50 countries in San Francisco at the conclusion of the United Nations Conference on International Organization.
events.significance: The charter established the United Nations, an international organization aimed at promoting peace, security, and cooperation among nations.

events.title: U.S. Congress Passes the Glass-Steagall Act
events.description: The Banking Act of 1933, commonly known as the Glass-Steagall Act, was enacted to separate commercial and investment banking and to provide banking reforms in response to the Great Depression.
events.significance: The act sought to restore public confidence in the banking system and reduce the risk of financial speculation that contributed to the 1929 stock market crash.

events.title: Independence of Ghana
events.description: Ghana gained independence from British colonial rule, becoming the first sub-Saharan African country to do so.
events.significance: Ghana's independence marked a major milestone in the wave of decolonization across Africa and inspired other nations to seek self-governance.

events.title: First Model T Ford Produced
events.description: The first Model T automobile was produced by the Ford Motor Company.
events.significance: The Model T was the first affordable automobile that opened car travel to the middle class, revolutionizing transportation and American industry.
